newsitem.title: UK: Brent crude paper up, wet barrels steady.
newsitem.headline: Brent crude paper up, wet barrels steady.

text.p: North Sea Brent gained on a very quiet paper market on Wednesday with intermonth spreads and contracts for difference both firming sharply, traders said.
June was 14 cents higher at $18.21 a barrel, seven cents off the day's high of $18.28, supported by bullish U.S. weekly inventory data.
On the Brent physical market one deal was reported -- a Wall Street trader sold a May 17-19 cargo to a European trader at a Dated Brent related price.
Earlier, Brent was thinly talked five cents weaker than Tuesday's trade level of June Brent -28 cents.
U.S. gasoline led the market after the DOE said that stocks suffered a draw of 2.4 million barrels in the May 2 week.
Brent intermonth spreads firmed, with a June/July traded at least once at -11 cents, or four cents higher than its best trade level on Tuesday.
The May/June spread firmed sharply, talked at -8/-5 cents from -20/-15 while Jul/Aug gained some three cents, bid at -12 cents.
Brent CFDs also tightened with a May 19-23 trading at least once at July Brent -30 cents, or the equivalent of June Brent -19 cents.
Next week's CFDs were talked some 16 cents sharper at June Brent -24 cents.
Traders said other North Sea crudes were steady or slightly higher.
A Norwegian major sold a May 18-20 cargo of Oseberg at Dated Brent +15 cents to a French refiner, one cent higher than a deal on Tuesday.
Forties was done twice at Dated Brent +22 on Tuesday "so I guess it will be a that level again", one European producer said. Norwegian Statfjord was around a 20 cent premium to Dated Brent, he added.
According to the May schedule no full Brent cargoes were going around the chains on Wednesday.
The Mediterranean Urals market was quiet but stable to firmer with one seller seeing a bid at Dated Brent -95 cents for an already committed last decade May cargo.
An offer of Dated Brent -$1.00 was heard for a cargo loading on Thursday May 8.

Traders looking at Iraqi crude saw one end May Kirkuk cargo for sale but said there was a possibility this would be cancelled were the price of crude to rise over the next two weeks, thus bringing the income from crude to above the U.N. agreed limit.
The United Nations oil-for-food deal allows Iraq to sell up to $2 billion worth of oil in a 180 day period (up to June 7) to raise money for humanitarian imports.
"It depends on where the price (for crude oil) goes over the next two weeks ...but it is perfectly possible a cargo would be cancelled," one trader said.
Talk that an end May cargo had been reduced in size from a one million barrel lifting to 600,000 barrels could not be confirmed immmediately.
West African markets were quiet and traders expected more barrels to trade to the East in the coming few days.
--H. Haddadin, S. Hayden, London newsroom +44 171 542 8145
